words.def: Acyclic. A binary relation is acyclic if it contains no "cycles": equivalently, its transitive closure is antisymmetric.[1]
words.name: Acyclic

words.def: Adjoint. See Galois connection.
words.name: Adjoint

words.def: Alexandrov topology. For a preordered set P, any upper set O is Alexandrov-open. Inversely, a topology is Alexandrov if any intersection of open sets is open.
words.name: Alexandrov topology

words.def: Algebraic poset. A poset is algebraic if it has a base of compact elements.
words.name: Algebraic poset

words.def: Antichain. An antichain is a poset in which no two elements are comparable, i.e., there are no two distinct elements x and y such that x ≤ y. In other words, the order relation of an antichain is just the identity relation.
words.name: Antichain

words.def: Approximates relation. See way-below relation.
words.name: Approximates relation

words.def: A relation R on a set X is antisymmetric, if x R y and y R x implies x = y, for all elements x, y in X.
words.name: antisymmetric

words.def: An antitone function f between posets P and Q is a function for which, for all elements x, y of P, x ≤ y (in P) implies f(y) ≤ f(x) (in Q). Another name for this property is order-reversing. In analysis, in the presence of total orders, such functions are often called monotonically decreasing, but this is not a very convenient description when dealing with non-total orders. The dual notion is called monotone or order-preserving.
words.name: antitone

words.def: Asymmetric. A relation R on a set X is asymmetric, if x R y implies not y R x, for all elements x, y in X.
words.name: Asymmetric

words.def: An atom in a poset P with least element 0, is an element that is minimal among all elements that are unequal to 0.
words.name: atom

words.def: A atomic poset P with least element 0 is one in which, for every non-zero element x of P, there is an atom a of P with a ≤ x.
words.name: atomic

words.def: Base. See continuous poset.
words.name: Base

words.def: A Boolean algebra is a distributive lattice with least element 0 and greatest element 1, in which every element x has a complement ¬x, such that x ∧ ¬x = 0 and x ∨ ¬x = 1.
words.name: Boolean algebra

words.def: A bounded poset is one that has a least element and a greatest element.
words.name: bounded

words.def: A poset is bounded complete if every of its subsets with some upper bound also has a least such upper bound. The dual notion is not common.
words.name: bounded complete

words.def: Chain. A chain is a totally ordered set or a totally ordered subset of a poset. See also total order.
words.name: Chain

words.def: Chain complete. A partially ordered set in which every chain has a least upper bound.
words.name: Chain complete

words.def: Closure operator. A closure operator on the poset P is a function C : P → P that is monotone, idempotent, and satisfies C(x) ≥ x for all x in P.
words.name: Closure operator

words.def: Compact. An element x of a poset is compact if it is way below itself, i.e. x<<x. One also says that such an x is finite.
words.name: Compact

words.def: Comparable. Two elements x and y of a poset P are comparable if either x ≤ y or y ≤ x.
words.name: Comparable

words.def: Comparability graph. The comparability graph of a poset (P, ≤) is the graph with vertex set P in which the edges are those pairs of distinct elements of P that are comparable under ≤ (and, in particular, under its reflexive reduction <).
words.name: Comparability graph

words.def: Complete Boolean algebra. A Boolean algebra that is a complete lattice.
words.name: Complete Boolean algebra

words.def: Complete Heyting algebra. A Heyting algebra that is a complete lattice is called a complete Heyting algebra. This notion coincides with the concepts frame and locale.
words.name: Complete Heyting algebra

words.def: Complete lattice. A complete lattice is a poset in which arbitrary (possibly infinite) joins (suprema) and meets (infima) exist.
words.name: Complete lattice

words.def: Complete partial order. A complete partial order, or cpo, is a directed complete partial order (q.v.) with least element.
words.name: Complete partial order

words.def: Complete relation. Synonym for Total relation.
words.name: Complete relation

words.def: Complete semilattice. The notion of a complete semilattice is defined in different ways. As explained in the article on completeness (order theory), any poset for which either all suprema or all infima exist is already a complete lattice. Hence the notion of a complete semilattice is sometimes used to coincide with the one of a complete lattice. In other cases, complete (meet-) semilattices are defined to be bounded complete cpos, which is arguably the most complete class of posets that are not already complete lattices.
words.name: Complete semilattice

words.def: Completely distributive lattice. A complete lattice is completely distributive if arbitrary joins distribute over arbitrary meets.
words.name: Completely distributive lattice

words.def: Completion. A completion of a poset is an order-embedding of the poset in a complete lattice.
words.name: Completion

words.def: Continuous poset. A poset is continuous if it has a base, i.e. a subset B of P such that every element x of P is the supremum of a directed set contained in {y in B | y<<x}.
words.name: Continuous poset

words.def: Continuous function. See Scott-continuous.
words.name: Continuous function

words.def: Converse. The converse <° of an order < is that in which x <° y whenever y < x.
words.name: Converse

words.def: Cover. An element y of a poset P is said to cover an element x of P (and is called a cover of x) if x < y and there is no element z of P such that x < z < y.
words.name: Cover

words.def: cpo. See complete partial order.
words.name: cpo

words.def: dcpo. See directed complete partial order.
words.name: dcpo

words.def: A dense poset P is one in which, for all elements x and y in P with x < y, there is an element z in P, such that x < z < y. A subset Q of P is dense in P if for any elements x < y in P, there is an element z in Q such that x < z < y.
words.name: dense

words.def: Directed. A non-empty subset X of a poset P is called directed, if, for all elements x and y of X, there is an element z of X such that x ≤ z and y ≤ z. The dual notion is called filtered.
words.name: Directed

words.def: Directed complete partial order. A poset D is said to be a directed complete poset, or dcpo, if every directed subset of D has a supremum.
words.name: Directed complete partial order

words.def: Distributive. A lattice L is called distributive if, for all x, y, and z in L, we find that x ∧ (y ∨ z) = (x ∧ y) ∨ (x ∧ z). This condition is known to be equivalent to its order dual. A meet-semilattice is distributive if for all elements a, b and x, a ∧ b ≤ x implies the existence of elements a' ≥ a and b' ≥ b such that a' ∧ b' = x. See also completely distributive.
words.name: Distributive

words.def: Domain. Domain is a general term for objects like those that are studied in domain theory. If used, it requires further definition.
words.name: Domain

words.def: Down-set. See lower set.
words.name: Down-set

words.def: Dual. For a poset (P, ≤), the dual order Pd = (P, ≥) is defined by setting x ≥ y if and only if y ≤ x. The dual order of P is sometimes denoted by Pop, and is also called opposite or converse order. Any order theoretic notion induces a dual notion, defined by applying the original statement to the order dual of a given set. This exchanges ≤ and ≥, meets and joins, zero and unit.
words.name: Dual

words.def: Extension. For partial orders ≤ and ≤′ on a set X, ≤′ is an extension of ≤ provided that for all elements x and y of X, x ≤ y implies that x ≤′ y.
words.name: Extension

words.def: Filter. A subset X of a poset P is called a filter if it is a filtered upper set. The dual notion is called ideal.
words.name: Filter

words.def: Filtered. A non-empty subset X of a poset P is called filtered, if, for all elements x and y of X, there is an element z of X such that z ≤ x and z ≤ y. The dual notion is called directed.
words.name: Filtered

words.def: Finite element. See compact.
words.name: Finite element

words.def:
Frame. A frame F is a complete lattice, in which, for every x in F and every subset Y of F, the infinite distributive law x ∧ 
  
    
      
        ⋁
      
    
    {\displaystyle \bigvee }
  
Y = 
  
    
      
        ⋁
      
    
    {\displaystyle \bigvee }
  
{x ∧ y | y in Y} holds. Frames are also known as locales and as complete Heyting algebras.
words.name: Frame

words.def: Galois connection. Given two posets P and Q, a pair of monotone functions F:P → Q and G:Q → P is called a Galois connection, if F(x) ≤ y is equivalent to x ≤ G(y), for all x in P and y in Q. F is called the lower adjoint of G and G is called the upper adjoint of F.
words.name: Galois connection

words.def: Greatest element. For a subset X of a poset P, an element a of X is called the greatest element of X, if x ≤ a for every element x in X. The dual notion is called least element.
words.name: Greatest element

words.def: Ground set. The ground set of a poset (X, ≤) is the set X on which the partial order ≤ is defined.
words.name: Ground set

words.def: Heyting algebra. A Heyting algebra H is a bounded lattice in which the function fa: H → H, given by fa(x) = a ∧ x is the lower adjoint of a Galois connection, for every element a of H. The upper adjoint of fa is then denoted by ga, with ga(x) = a ⇒ x. Every Boolean algebra is a Heyting algebra.
words.name: Heyting algebra

words.def: Hasse diagram. A Hasse diagram is a type of mathematical diagram used to represent a finite partially ordered set, in the form of a drawing of its transitive reduction.
words.name: Hasse diagram

words.def: An ideal is a subset X of a poset P that is a directed lower set. The dual notion is called filter.
words.name: ideal

words.def: The incidence algebra of a poset is the associative algebra of all scalar-valued functions on intervals, with addition and scalar multiplication defined pointwise, and multiplication defined as a certain convolution; see incidence algebra for the details.
words.name: incidence algebra

words.def:
Infimum. For a poset P and a subset X of P, the greatest element in the set of lower bounds of X (if it exists, which it may not) is called the infimum, meet, or greatest lower bound of X. It is denoted by inf X or 
  
    
      
        ⋀
      
    
    {\displaystyle \bigwedge }
  
X. The infimum of two elements may be written as inf{x,y} or x ∧ y. If the set X is finite, one speaks of a finite infimum. The dual notion is called supremum.
words.name: Infimum

words.def: Interval. For two elements a, b of a partially ordered set P, the interval [a,b] is the subset {x in P | a ≤ x ≤ b} of P. If a ≤ b does not hold the interval will be empty.
words.name: Interval

words.def: Interval finite poset. A partially ordered set P is interval finite if every interval of the form {x in P | x ≤ a} is a finite set.[2]
words.name: Interval finite poset

words.def: Inverse. See converse.
words.name: Inverse

words.def: Irreflexive. A relation R on a set X is irreflexive, if there is no element x in X such that x R x.
words.name: Irreflexive

words.def: Isotone. See monotone.
words.name: Isotone

words.def: Join. See supremum.
words.name: Join

words.def: Lattice. A lattice is a poset in which all non-empty finite joins (suprema) and meets (infima) exist.
words.name: Lattice

words.def: Least element. For a subset X of a poset P, an element a of X is called the least element of X, if a ≤ x for every element x in X. The dual notion is called greatest element.
words.name: Least element

words.def: The length of a chain is the number of elements less one. A chain with 1 element has length 0, one with 2 elements has length 1, etc.
words.name: length

words.def: Linear. See total order.
words.name: Linear

words.def: Linear extension. A linear extension of a partial order is an extension that is a linear order, or total order.
words.name: Linear extension

words.def: Locale. A locale is a complete Heyting algebra. Locales are also called frames and appear in Stone duality and pointless topology.
words.name: Locale

words.def: Locally finite poset. A partially ordered set P is locally finite if every interval [a, b] = {x in P | a ≤ x ≤ b} is a finite set.
words.name: Locally finite poset

words.def: Lower bound. A lower bound of a subset X of a poset P is an element b of P, such that b ≤ x, for all x in X. The dual notion is called upper bound.
words.name: Lower bound

words.def: Lower set. A subset X of a poset P is called a lower set if, for all elements x in X and p in P, p ≤ x implies that p is contained in X. The dual notion is called upper set.
words.name: Lower set

words.def: Maximal chain. A chain in a poset to which no element can be added without losing the property of being totally ordered. This is stronger than being a saturated chain, as it also excludes the existence of elements either less than all elements of the chain or greater than all its elements. A finite saturated chain is maximal if and only if it contains both a minimal and a maximal element of the poset.
words.name: Maximal chain

words.def: Maximal element. A maximal element of a subset X of a poset P is an element m of X, such that m ≤ x implies m = x, for all x in X. The dual notion is called minimal element.
words.name: Maximal element

words.def: Maximum element. Synonym of greatest element. For a subset X of a poset P, an element a of X is called the maximum element of X if x ≤ a for every element x in X. A maximum element is necessarily maximal, but the converse need not hold.
words.name: Maximum element

words.def: Meet. See infimum.
words.name: Meet

words.def: Minimal element. A minimal element of a subset X of a poset P is an element m of X, such that x ≤ m implies m = x, for all x in X. The dual notion is called maximal element.
words.name: Minimal element

words.def: Minimum element. Synonym of least element. For a subset X of a poset P, an element a of X is called the minimum element of X if x ≥ a for every element x in X. A minimum element is necessarily minimal, but the converse need not hold.
words.name: Minimum element

words.def: Monotone. A function f between posets P and Q is monotone if, for all elements x, y of P, x ≤ y (in P) implies f(x) ≤ f(y) (in Q). Other names for this property are isotone and order-preserving. In analysis, in the presence of total orders, such functions are often called monotonically increasing, but this is not a very convenient description when dealing with non-total orders. The dual notion is called antitone or order reversing.
words.name: Monotone

words.def: Order-dual. The order dual of a partially ordered set is the same set with the partial order relation replaced by its converse.
words.name: Order-dual

words.def: Order-embedding. A function f between posets P and Q is an order-embedding if, for all elements x, y of P, x ≤ y (in P) is equivalent to f(x) ≤ f(y) (in Q).
words.name: Order-embedding

words.def: Order isomorphism. A mapping f: P → Q between two posets P and Q is called an order isomorphism, if it is bijective and both f and f−1 are monotone. Equivalently, an order isomorphism is a surjective order embedding.
words.name: Order isomorphism

words.def: Order-preserving. See monotone.
words.name: Order-preserving

words.def: Order-reversing. See antitone.
words.name: Order-reversing

words.def: Partial order. A partial order is a binary relation that is reflexive, antisymmetric, and transitive. In a slight abuse of terminology, the term is sometimes also used to refer not to such a relation, but to its corresponding partially ordered set.
words.name: Partial order

words.def: Poset. A partially ordered set.
words.name: Poset

words.def: Preorder. A preorder is a binary relation that is reflexive and transitive. Such orders may also be called quasiorders. The term preorder is also used to denote an acyclic binary relation (also called an acyclic digraph).
words.name: Preorder

words.def: Preserving. A function f between posets P and Q is said to preserve suprema (joins), if, for all subsets X of P that have a supremum sup X in P, we find that sup{f(x): x in X} exists and is equal to f(sup X). Such a function is also called join-preserving. Analogously, one says that f preserves finite, non-empty, directed, or arbitrary joins (or meets). The converse property is called join-reflecting.
words.name: Preserving

words.def: Prime. An ideal I in a lattice L is said to be prime, if, for all elements x and y in L, x ∧ y in I implies x in I or y in I. The dual notion is called a prime filter. Equivalently, a set is a prime filter if and only if its complement is a prime ideal.
words.name: Prime

words.def: Principal. A filter is called principal filter if it has a least element. Dually, a principal ideal is an ideal with a greatest element. The least or greatest elements may also be called principal elements in these situations.
words.name: Principal

words.def: Projection (operator). A self-map on a partially ordered set that is monotone and idempotent under function composition. Projections play an important role in domain theory.
words.name: Projection (operator)

words.def: Pseudo-complement. In a Heyting algebra, the element x ⇒ 0 is called the pseudo-complement of x. It is also given by sup{y : y ∧ x = 0}, i.e. as the least upper bound of all elements y with y ∧ x = 0.
words.name: Pseudo-complement

words.def: Quasiorder. See preorder.
words.name: Quasiorder

words.def: Quasitransitive. A relation is quasitransitive if the relation on distinct elements is transitive. Transitive implies quasitransitive and quasitransitive implies acyclic.[1]
words.name: Quasitransitive

words.def: Reflecting. A function f between posets P and Q is said to reflect suprema (joins), if, for all subsets X of P for which the supremum sup{f(x): x in X} exists and is of the form f(s) for some s in P, then we find that sup X exists and that sup X = s . Analogously, one says that f reflects finite, non-empty, directed, or arbitrary joins (or meets). The converse property is called join-preserving.
words.name: Reflecting

words.def: Reflexive. A binary relation R on a set X is reflexive, if x R x holds for all elements x, y in X.
words.name: Reflexive

words.def: Residual. A dual map attached to a residuated mapping.
words.name: Residual

words.def: Residuated mapping. A monotone map for which the preimage of a principal down-set is again principal. Equivalently, one component of a Galois connection.
words.name: Residuated mapping

words.def: Saturated chain. A chain such that no element can be added between two of its elements without losing the property of being totally ordered. If the chain is finite, this means that in every pair of successive elements the larger one covers the smaller one. See also maximal chain.
words.name: Saturated chain

words.def: Scattered. A total order is scattered if it has no densely ordered subset.
words.name: Scattered

words.def: Scott-continuous. A monotone function f : P → Q between posets P and Q is Scott-continuous if, for every directed set D that has a supremum sup D in P, the set {fx | x in D} has the supremum f(sup D) in Q. Stated differently, a Scott-continuous function is one that preserves all directed suprema. This is in fact equivalent to being continuous with respect to the Scott topology on the respective posets.
words.name: Scott-continuous

words.def: Scott domain. A Scott domain is a partially ordered set which is a bounded complete algebraic cpo.
words.name: Scott domain

words.def: Scott open. See Scott topology.
words.name: Scott open

words.def: Scott topology. For a poset P, a subset O is Scott-open if it is an upper set and all directed sets D that have a supremum in O have non-empty intersection with O. The set of all Scott-open sets forms a topology, the Scott topology.
words.name: Scott topology

words.def: Semilattice. A semilattice is a poset in which either all finite non-empty joins (suprema) or all finite non-empty meets (infima) exist. Accordingly, one speaks of a join-semilattice or meet-semilattice.
words.name: Semilattice

words.def: Smallest element. See least element.
words.name: Smallest element

words.def: Strict order. A strict order is a binary relation that is antisymmetric, transitive, and irreflexive.
words.name: Strict order

words.def:
Supremum. For a poset P and a subset X of P, the least element in the set of upper bounds of X (if it exists, which it may not) is called the supremum, join, or least upper bound of X. It is denoted by sup X or 
  
    
      
        ⋁
      
    
    {\displaystyle \bigvee }
  
X. The supremum of two elements may be written as sup{x,y} or x ∨ y. If the set X is finite, one speaks of a finite supremum. The dual notion is called infimum.
words.name: Supremum

words.def: Suzumura consistency. A binary relation R is Suzumura consistent if x R∗ y implies that x R y or not y R x.[1]
words.name: Suzumura consistency

words.def: Symmetric. A relation R on a set X is symmetric, if x R y implies y R x, for all elements x, y in X.
words.name: Symmetric

words.def: Top. See unit.
words.name: Top

words.def: Total order. A total order T is a partial order in which, for each x and y in T, we have x ≤ y or y ≤ x. Total orders are also called linear orders or chains.
words.name: Total order

words.def: Total relation. A total or complete relation R on a set X has the property that for all elements x, y of X, at least one of x R y or y R x holds.
words.name: Total relation

words.def: Transitive. A relation R on a set X is transitive, if x R y and y R z imply x R z, for all elements x, y, z in X.
words.name: Transitive

words.def: Transitive closure. The transitive closure R∗ of a relation R consists of all pairs x,y for which there cists a finite chain x R a, a R b, ..., z R y.[1]
words.name: Transitive closure

words.def: Unit. The greatest element of a poset P can be called unit or just 1 (if it exists). Another common term for this element is top. It is the infimum of the empty set and the supremum of P. The dual notion is called zero.
words.name: Unit

words.def: Up-set. See upper set.
words.name: Up-set

words.def: Upper bound. An upper bound of a subset X of a poset P is an element b of P, such that x ≤ b, for all x in X. The dual notion is called lower bound.
words.name: Upper bound

words.def: Upper set. A subset X of a poset P is called an upper set if, for all elements x in X and p in P, x ≤ p implies that p is contained in X. The dual notion is called lower set.
words.name: Upper set

words.def:
Valuation. Given a lattice 
  
    
      
        X
      
    
    {\displaystyle X}
  
, a valuation 
  
    
      
        ν
        :
        X
        →
        [
        0
        ,
        1
        ]
      
    
    {\displaystyle \nu :X\to [0,1]}
  
 is strict (i.e., 
  
    
      
        ν
        (
        ∅
        )
        =
        0
      
    
    {\displaystyle \nu (\emptyset )=0}
  
), monotone, modular (i.e., 
  
    
      
        ν
        (
        U
        )
        +
        ν
        (
        V
        )
        =
        ν
        (
        U
        ∪
        V
        )
        +
        ν
        (
        U
        ∩
        V
        )
      
    
    {\displaystyle \nu (U)+\nu (V)=\nu (U\cup V)+\nu (U\cap V)}
  
) and positive. Continuous valuations are a generalization of measures.
words.name: Valuation

words.def: Way-below relation. In a poset P, some element x is way below y, written x<<y, if for all directed subsets D of P which have a supremum, y ≤ sup D implies x ≤ d for some d in D. One also says that x approximates y. See also domain theory.
words.name: Way-below relation

words.def: Weak order. A partial order ≤ on a set X is a weak order provided that the poset (X, ≤) is isomorphic to a countable collection of sets ordered by comparison of cardinality.
words.name: Weak order

words.def: Zero. The least element of a poset P can be called zero or just 0 (if it exists). Another common term for this element is bottom. Zero is the supremum of the empty set and the infimum of P. The dual notion is called unit.
words.name: Zero
